subject: Document expectations for commit messages
commitMessage:
Document expectations for commit messages

This commit tries to be more explicit about the expectations for commit
messages and testing within bmcweb, and give maintainers something to
point to instead of repeating the same statements over and over again.

This will likely need to evolve, but I think it's a good start, and
would help people put together commits that can be merged on the first
try, rather than requiring followup.

Tested: Documentation only, no testing.

Signed-off-by: Ed Tanous <edtanous@google.com>
Change-Id: Ib60ac90eccdc4f2c3215a755bbb462fff4796dd4

Should any of this go in openbmc/docs or should we link there? I like to see as much of our contributing documentation go there so it spans the whole project. 

E.g. 

"14. ### Commit messages
   Commit messages should answer the following questions:

   - Why are the changes useful?  Given that bmcweb is a user-facing daemon,
      commits adding new functionality should include statements about how the
      commit in question is useful to the user.
      Exception: documentation changes, and bug fixes do not need justification.

   - What changes would a user expect to see?  This includes new parameters, new
     resources, and new or changed properties.  Any route changes should be
     explicitly called out.

   - Are there compatibility concerns?  Is this change backward compatible for
     clients?  if not, what commit would be broken, and how old is it?   have
     clients been warned? (ideally on the mailing list)  link the discussion.

As documented in https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#formatting-commit-messages we follow https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/. As documented, commit messages should be line wrapped at 50/72."

or 

14. ### Commit messages
bmcweb follows https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#formatting-commit-messages. 

Some bmcweb specific things to consider in a commit message: 
   - Why are the changes useful?  Given that bmcweb is a user-facing daemon,
      commits adding new functionality should include statements about how the
      commit in question is useful to the user.
      Exception: documentation changes, and bug fixes do not need justification.

   - What changes would a user expect to see?  This includes new parameters, new
     resources, and new or changed properties.  Any route changes should be
     explicitly called out.

   - Are there compatibility concerns?  Is this change backward compatible for
     clients?  if not, what commit would be broken, and how old is it?   have
     clients been warned? (ideally on the mailing list)  link the discussion.

> Should any of this go in openbmc/docs or should we link there? I like to see as much of our contributing documentation go there so it spans the whole project. 

Agreed, we should link there.  I suspect that we'll always have a bmcweb specific section, as there are specifics to redfish that need documented somewhere.

> As documented in https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#formatting-commit-messages we follow https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/. As documented, commit messages should be line wrapped at 50/72."

nitpick: just seems like odd styling of a name. Greg Kroah-Hartman ? Greg K-H as from https://twitter.com/gregkh?lang=en?

I would like to see some more concrete rules here. E.g 

Any breaking api change even if behind a compile flag will be sent to the mailing list. 
Any breaking api change will have a transition period of 1 openbmc release, roughly 6 months.

A breaking api change might look like the following: 
Send email to the list and place new behavior behind a meson option defaulted to the existing behavior.
Following the release, change the default to be the new behavior and added appropriate deprecation warnings to the old behavior. 
Following the 2nd release, remove the meson option and the old behavior.

Note: Are we having openbmc releases anymore?
Think we need to have some more discussion here.

> I would like to see some more concrete rules here. E.g 
> 
> Any breaking api change even if behind a compile flag will be sent to the mailing list. 
> Any breaking api change will have a transition period of 1 openbmc release, roughly 6 months.

I'd like rules here too, but I intentionally avoided them because this was supposed to be the uncontroversial commit 😊  I'm sure people will have strong opinions on compatibility and breakages considering how many patches try to break compatibility.

> 
> A breaking api change might look like the following: 
> Send email to the list and place new behavior behind a meson option defaulted to the existing behavior.
> Following the release, change the default to be the new behavior and added appropriate deprecation warnings to the old behavior. 
> Following the 2nd release, remove the meson option and the old behavior.

All of this is great, but unless it's really needed as part of this, I'd like to do it in the next patch (which I'm happy to write).  For the moment, I'd like to keep this scoped on documenting "What is a breaking change?"  Once everyone is agreed on that, we can start on a "So you want to make a breaking change?" section, which is kind of what you're getting at.

> 
> Note: Are we having openbmc releases anymore?

IDK, but when we write this, lets scope it on dates that line up with the approximate release boundaries so that we're not explicitly tied to them, but can tie ourselves to them if we choose.

> Think we need to have some more discussion here.

> All of this is great, but unless it's really needed as part of this, I'd like to do it in the next patch (which I'm happy to write).  For the moment, I'd like to keep this scoped on documenting "What is a breaking change?"  Once everyone is agreed on that, we can start on a "So you want to make a breaking change?" section, which is kind of what you're getting at.

I am still struggling a bit here this section just feels larger incomplete. It isn't like reviewers can point at this section and be done because there aren't really any actions behind this. 
E.g. I can say "Common Error 5" and the author can look at the common errors document and understand what must be done. 

That said, this paragraph is 3 things: example of other open source code (kernel) having compatibility rules, why compatibility is important to bmcweb, and what compatibility we are concerned about. 

All should be documented and I can get on board with come back later with rules around compatibility.  

> IDK, but when we write this, lets scope it on dates that line up with the approximate release boundaries so that we're not explicitly tied to them, but can tie ourselves to them if we choose.

I like this.

> > All of this is great, but unless it's really needed as part of this, I'd like to do it in the next patch (which I'm happy to write).  For the moment, I'd like to keep this scoped on documenting "What is a breaking change?"  Once everyone is agreed on that, we can start on a "So you want to make a breaking change?" section, which is kind of what you're getting at.
> 
> I am still struggling a bit here this section just feels larger incomplete. It isn't like reviewers can point at this section and be done because there aren't really any actions behind this. 
> E.g. I can say "Common Error 5" and the author can look at the common errors document and understand what must be done. 
> 
> That said, this paragraph is 3 things: example of other open source code (kernel) having compatibility rules, why compatibility is important to bmcweb, and what compatibility we are concerned about. 
> 
> All should be documented and I can get on board with come back later with rules around compatibility.  

Lets try to refine this in a future patch;  I intentionally tried to not be explicit with examples, under the assumption those examples would then be used as a complete list of all possible compatibility issues in the future, which is a neverending list.

> 
> > IDK, but when we write this, lets scope it on dates that line up with the approximate release boundaries so that we're not explicitly tied to them, but can tie ourselves to them if we choose.
> 
> I like this.

Nitpick: unnecessary comma 
I would actually be in favor of just leaving these exceptions out.
I hope bug fixes would come with a "why these changes are useful". And the 2nd sentence only applies to new function...
Even documentation in most cases should state "why it is needed". I just don't think this sentence does much.

> Nitpick: unnecessary comma 
> I would actually be in favor of just leaving these exceptions out.
> I hope bug fixes would come with a "why these changes are useful". And the 2nd sentence only applies to new function...

Sure, seems reasonable.

> Even documentation in most cases should state "why it is needed". I just don't think this sentence does much.

Agreed, it's too much, although documentation is itself.... documentation, so it's a little meta, but I think we can handle that on a case by case basis.  I just just trying to avoid commits with "documentation is a good thing".
What about a change made in the name of security, some permission change?

I didn't think it needed to be called out explicitly.   A number of security changes are visible to users, and a number aren't, so I didn't think it deserved its own callout, but what did you have in mind?

I was thinking 
"- In the best interest of security" 
"- For security fixes"  
or something like that but I am fine if you want to leave off
I kinda lumped that in with new items added to a collection (given that a correctly implemented new schema would require a new odata link) but sure, we can call it out explicitly.  ACK
